headline: Easy Pressure Cooker Pot Roast
description: This pressure cooker pot roast recipe is a real time-saver and allows you to make the most tender and delicious seasoned beef any night of the week.

video.description: This easy pot roast cooks all in pot!
video.name: Easy Pressure Cooker Pot Roast

name: Easy Pressure Cooker Pot Roast
recipeIngredient: 1 (3 pound) boneless beef chuck roast, trimmed
1 pinch seasoned salt, or to taste
1 pinch onion powder, or to taste
4 large potatoes, peeled and cut into bite-size pieces
4 carrots, peeled and cut into bite-size pieces

recipeInstructions.text: Heat oil in a pressure cooker over medium-high heat. Sear roast on all sides in hot oil until browned; season with salt, onion powder, and pepper.
Pour in beef broth and Worcestershire sauce; add onion and seal the lid. Bring the cooker up to full pressure. Reduce heat to low, maintaining full pressure, and cook for 30 minutes.
Use the quick-release method to lower the pressure. Stir in potatoes and carrots and seal the lid; bring the cooker up to full pressure and cook for an additional 15 minutes.
Use the quick-release method again and transfer roast and vegetables to a serving dish.

review.reviewBody: I was afraid I'd mess it up after reading some reviews. However, followed the recipe and came out tender and flavorful! This is a keeper! Yummy!!
Very tender and tasty. I did add a lot of other spices.
This recipe makes the roast super tough. If you want a fall apart roast, this is NOT the recipe for you. I will not be making this again. What a waste of food.
I cooked it from frozen for 1-1/2 hours It was quite tender
Super duper tough, the toughest pot roast I’ve ever made. The veggies were mush and the pot roast I had to cut with a meat clever. Will not use the recipe again.

So excited! This was my first homemade roast and it tastes just like my mom's. The only changes I made was I added 4 garlic cloves to the onion and spices, and I added celery when putting in the carrots and potatos.
It was easy and delicious.....

I was ready to love this, but for some reason my roast was tough! I only had a 1.5 pound roast so maybe it was my fault? The flavor was good, but I did add Dash garlic and Herb when adding potatoes, etc.
Easy, simple, quick, fun, delicious!
This turned out delicious! I added with squash and parsley. It needed more spices and maybe a jalapeño. It was a really good recipe!
It was amazing!!! I did add 10 more minutes because the roast was thicker on one side
Made this recipe my husband and I did not change anything.

I added Sazon to beef and onions, didnt have season all. Sprinkled my own seasonings on potatoes and carrots b4 adding to pressure cooker. Went in with Mrs. Dash table blend @ the end. I always do extra to simple recipes.

So good! It melts in your mouth! I didn't have potatoes, so I just went without. It was so flavorful and moist! Amazing!
The pressure cooker made it so fast too!
I made a modified version of this. Half a chuck roast steak slab and no brown sugar, but it tastes so good!
best pot roast ever. instead of beef broth, used better than boullion mixed with hot water. made very flavorful gravy also

I have an Crockpot express XL. It came out really good I just extended time to an hour and 15 minutes, I used a 10.5 oz can of beef broth and added 4oz of water and a tablespoon of better than bouillon to make sure It had enough flavor. I then added 3table spoons of flour to my juice to make a gravy, added carrots and potatoes pressure Cooked for another 10 min they came out Just right
Needs garlic. I use a bit of English Prime Rib Rub from Penzey’s Spices. A lot of garlic, onion and celery.

Flavor is good. Cooking time needs adjustment. Pot roast is supposed to fall apart, not need to be sawed through. I had to remove the veggies to finish cooking the roast. By the time the roast was done, the veggies were cold.

Great recipe! Added a pinch of coriander and rosemary in step 1.
Came out tender and falls apart. Delish!!!!
Made it per the recipe. It is really tasty. And east. And I made gravy with all the juices.
Excellent turnout on this pot roast! I sear my roast in a skillet, otherwise I get a burn warning on the pressure cooker.

I made this last night. It was excellent! It took slightly over an hour including prep time, and tasted like it had simmered for hours. The meat was very tender, juicy, and very tasty. I used a one lb. bag of baby carrots and a one lb. bag of petite potatoes for quicker prep.
so easy. I just did onion and carrot with the meat since I have left over mashed potatoes. Thank you for the recipe.

I agree with other comments that the flavor profile needed a bit more pizzazz. For a Caribbean Flavor dish I would add thyme, allspice and a sliced jalapeno. There was a lot of liquid so I would also cut back the tomato sauce to 8 ounces. The vegies came out very soft - I would cut them into very large pieces. I made the seasoning blend and used it as a rub for the roast. Beef tasted great! I think because of all the sauce, the flavors got diluted.

One thing I definitely want to add is don't quick release your meat, this will make the meat super tough. Once the time is up you let it slow release on its own. This will make the most tender pot roast! And another thing add a dry packet of liptons soup mix to your roast before cooking for more flavor!! Other than that it's a good recipe
loved it ! thank you
Good recipe. Made it in 4 qt. Crockpot Express. Coated 2.1 lbs. choice chuck roast in A1 sauce.
Easy to follow, fast, and turned out pretty spot on.
Very good. Added rosemary and celery salt.

In lieu of the beef broth, I used a can of Campbell's French onion soup and a can of water, 5 decent sized Idaho potatoes and a whole small bag of baby carrots. Since I was using the onion soup, I only added half an onion. Was very good and quickly disappeared.

Followed exactly. Like other reviews the roast turned out tough. 30 minutes low followed by 15 high. Disappointed. Recipe and video not clear on high or low for pressure cooker settings. Waste of a good cut of meat.
I found this to be very dry and overcooked.
I served this at a dinner party tonight and got nothing but compliments, including from my wife. ;-)

This was my first try using a pressure cooker. Took me a few minutes to figure everything out. Meat was tender and flavorful along with the vegetables. Sure beats waiting all day for the same flavor. Will definitely make it again.
I loved it husband thought it was missing something. Still he did have seconds. We will have this again
Really good. I could’ve left my roast under pressure longer but the meal tasted great.
This recipe was excellent! The ingredients, the cook times, and the directions were perfect, wouldn't change a thing. Served over cooked ziti.
Great recipe. Cooked the potatoes and carrots on for 8 minutes came out perfect!
Very easy to make. Next time I will use a better cut of meat, but my chuck roast, which is what I had handy did good is coming out fairly soft, it's just too much fat.

This recipe was ridiculously easy to follow and the roast amazing. There were no left overs as my family thoroughly enjoyed every bite. I will definitely add this to my list of instant pot go to recipes.
Very easy! Smells terrific and taste is awesome!!
I had to make some minor changes due to cooker size, but the flavor was still very good. I love my pressure cooker!

I pretty much stuck to the recipe except I sprinkled a little McCormick's Montreal Steak Seasoning on the meat and left off the pepper. I increased the time the meat was in the pressure cooker and it fell apart! It was great! I will definitely make this again!
I didn't have Worcestershire sauce so used steak sauce. That was the only change I made. I removed everything when done and thickened broth for gravy. Delicious!

This was delicious and so fast for what is usually an all-day meal. Used a bone-in arm roast (highly recommend for flavor), added a bit of my favorite flavors of garlic, red wine, and thyme and cut back 5 mins of cook time on the veggies (kept them a little firm). Will make this again and again!
As-is wasn't so great...

Delicious, I added to the recipie 1 tbl spn Garlic powder, 4 tbl spns Badia Complete seasoning, left out the salt. 
also added 1 cup sliced white mushrooms.
Easy. Flavorful. Will make again! Took me back to Mom’s Sunday dinner in the 1960’s.
My roast was 4lbs. I did my own little twist on my recipe. I made the roast and let it rest on keep warm for an hour. I then added my vegetables. It turned out so moist and tasty.

It seems to be a good jumping off point to experiment. There really is no way to mess this up. I use new potatoes and three cups of broth. There are 6-8 of us eating at any one time and we have zero leftovers. It is important to note that you will have to make this a couple of times to figure out what will work for you.
Used this method (with different spices) to cook a big sirloin for shredding for tacos. PERFECT!
Decided to make this at the last minute but didn’t have carrots so I double the potatoes. It tasted amazing.
Only thing I will say is it was awesome! No complaints. Leftovers made for a not so bad Stroganoff as well. I have to trick them into eating leftovers. Shhh...
This was a really good recipe. I added fresh garlic, cilantro and parsley. The taste was great. If there was a bone it would have fallen off the bone. Succulent and easy....
This is a family favorite! We change up the vegetables often, but otherwise follow this recipe to the letter. My kids beg me to make it at least once a month. It’s so quick and easy!
Simple to prepare, smelled divine while cooking, DELICIOUS & didn't take all day!
Just a very simple recipe that always turns out flavorful and delicious. I only made one change which was to use Better Than Bullion and water instead of broth.

Before I made this I read a lot of the reviews and did alter the recipe a little. 

I have made this a few times since I like it so much. 

I do cook the meat longer and cook the veggies less.

I made this for dinner tonight. Delicious!! I followed the recipe but when I placed the vegetable in the pot I added some minced garlic and a 1/2 teaspoon of beef base. Also I thickened the gravy with some flour and then brought the pressure back up and cooked for 15 min. I will certainly make this again.
Used a shoulder roast - increased time to 1 hour. Very good and no mess at all.

I added sweet potatoes instead of carrots; and a can of tomatoes and a package of onion soup mix. The meat wasn't quite tender enough so I removed, sliced and cooked an additional 15 minutes under pressure. I use a pressure cooker as I have not purchased one of the instapots yet. I accompanied my meal with gravy made from the broth and roasted cauliflower and brussel sprouts. My family loved it on a cold winter night.

Used blade roast, used garlic salt instead of plain salt. Everything else the same. First time using a pressure cooker and we LOVED the tenderness of the meat and the carrots were heavenly. Potatoes didn't ring any bells. Next time I would quadruple the carrots and skip the spuds. Will try injecting the meat with soy and honey.

I have a traditional pressure cooker, not an instant pot.
I trimmed almost all the fat so it was pretty lean, and it came out great! Tasted better than when I slow cook a roast for 6 or 7 hours. This is the way I will make it from now on. It was tender, fall apart, perfectly cooked. 

Changes I made: cooked 5 lbs of meat instead of 3, kept liquid as mentioned but added 1/4 cup red wine. Did not want to add the veggies in with the meat, so I left it in the cooker for the whole 45 min.
Everything turned out as expected and tender meat and juicy but not over cooked vegetable- the entire family said it was excellent.-thank you
I wish the recipe said to put the plate in the bottom of the pot. Some recipes want you to use it while others don’t. Anyway mine burned badly. I will try it again but this time I will use the plate.
I wish the recipe said to put the plate in the bottom of the pot. Some recipes want you to use it while others don’t. Anyway mine burned badly. I will try it again but this time I will use the plate.
Quick and tasty

This dish came out great.
The chuck roast that I used was very tender and flavorful.
I might use more root vegetables,as the carrots and potatoes pretty much disintergrated.
Just perfect
Made it just like the recipe says, but next time I think I'll add some dried herbs too.
Awesome
I followed your recipe exactly and my roast turned out great! I served it with hot french bread and a salad. Thanks for the great recipe! I'll be making more of this!
It was very tender! I will make it again but next time adding more seasons to it ??
3 pound chuck cooking time needs to be increased by 30 minutes at least bland as well wasn't satisfied
This was delicious and very easy. So glad I found this recipe. Will be making this again.
The meat and veggies were nice and tender, but the recipe is very bland. The next time I make it, I'll use 2 envelopes of Lipton Onion Soup mix in place of beef broth and 2 cups ketchup.

Easy and delicious and economical! I added in some celery (because I love celery) and I think it made it even better. 

Consider less time on the second pressure cook. The potatoes were a bit mushy. Probably could have just done 10m vs. 15m.

I'll be making this a lot this winter!

Delicious, I made a few adjustments based on what I had and suggestions I saw in other reviews! I used Marsala dry wine and beef stock and added mushrooms to vegetables! Cooked it in a cast iron Dutch oven with lid and after browning the meat as in the recipe, I placed it in a 250 degree oven for 2 hours, then increased the temp to 325 degrees for another 2 hours, adding the carrots and potatoes the last hour! I think the cast iron Dutch oven cooks hotter so the lower temp and adding more beef stock as needed prevented burning! Delicious meal!!
I added mushrooms.....1/2 with the meat and then 1/2 with the potatoes and carrots. The mushrooms added with the beef came out much better. Next time I will add all of them with the beef. Very tasty!

I added garlic to the meat while browning it. When pressure cooking the meat I cooked it for 40min on high with thyme on top of the meat. The meat was perfect and tender! I added mushrooms, carrots and potatoes after the meat was done cooking. I read the reviews before making this recipe and I agree that 15min is too long for the veggies to be pressure cooked. I went with 10 and although the potatoes held together they almost were too soft. - - - I made a delicious gravy to go along with this meal by using the broth, garlic powder, onion powder and a touch of milk along with flour. This was one of the best meals I have prepared in awhile. I highly recommend this recipe especially if you go the extra step to add a few more herbs and spices.

This was terrific. I'm rating 4 stars on the original recipe, but reading the reviews I made changes that make it a 5 star meal for sure. It is so tender I ate the meat using a fork only; a knife is unnecessary. It is hard to mess this up. Here is what I did:

-Did not brown the roast.
-Placed large chunks of carrot, celery, onion on the bottom.
-Heavily salted the 3 pound roast, then placed in the instapot.
-Added about 4 cups of beef broth.
-Added a splash of red wine, worchestershire, pepper, garlic, rosemary, and thyme. 
-Set the instapot for 1 hr 15 min, and left it alone.
(I wanted mashed potatoes, so I just prepared those separately.) The roast came out so tender and tasted fantastic, but I like salt and added a dash more at the table. We'll follow someone else's idea and thicken the broth, then add noodles to make a soup tonight or tomorrow. This meal is a keeper...just add more spices than the recipe calls for.
Very good, tender. Flavorful broth to make gravy. Would make again.

This is an ---EXCELLENT--- recipe - Very Tender and Tasty! Like many others who commented, I made some modifications. Instead of a "Pot Roast" I used a Tri-Tip Roast (about 3-4 lbs., fat-cap included). I blotted the roast dry with paper towel; seasoned both sides with Kosher Salt; coated all sides with Wondra Flour. Using my Farberware Electric Pressure Cooker I browned all sides in EVOO on SEAR setting. Instead of Onion Powder, I used 1 Lipton Onion Soup Mix packet and sprinkled all over top of roast along with an unmeasured sprinkle of Garlic Granules (about 1-2 TBLS) and generous sprinkling of Coarse Ground Malabar Black Pepper. I poured 32 ounces of Swanson Beef Stock over the top; omitted the Worcestershire Sauce completely; quartered 4-5 small Red Onions & placed on top; quartered 4-5 medium-sized Red Bliss Potatoes and place on top. I would have put Carrots in, but no room. I placed lid on, selected STEAK/MEAT setting; adjusted the time to 60 minutes & hit START button. Once done, I did a Quick-Release; removed Onions & Potatoes to a bowl and Roast to a platter (easily scrapping off & discarding all the fat-cap without sacrificing any meat (fat came off like softened butter). Selected SEAR setting again & brought liquid to boil, added Wondra Flour to thicken liquid to gravy consistency; put roast & vege's back in pot, put lid on/locked it. Selected KEEP WARM to keep warm until serving time.
I actually used a tri tip roast, which was on sale at our local supermarket and it was excellent this way. Thank you.
I recently discovered using a pressure cooker for pot roast. I love how it cooks the roast, but the veggies are mush. Last time I made it, I roasted them instead, then added them.

This was fantastic. I used a tablespoon of beef Better Than Bullion and 2 cups of water in place of the can of beef broth. I also doubled the carrots and made mashed potatoes on the side. I sprinkled garlic powder and onion powder salt and pepper with a sprinkle of Tony Chachere’s. It was extremely tender and the carrots were fantastic! I have made it several times I always use different spices ... whatever I have on hand, and it has turned out great every time.
Very good and very easy. The roast was perfectly cooked, as were the vegetables. And the broth made a great gravy.

I made this in my Instant Pot this evening and it came out great! Potatoes and carrots were just a little softer (not mushy, just softer) than I like, so next time I'll cut back to 10 - 12 minutes. Also added some slivers of fresh garlic, a bay leaf, some extra salt and doubled up on the Worcestershire. Didn't have beef broth so just used a couple of bullion cubes in hot water. Thickened up the sauce by making a slurry with a couple of teaspoons of cornstarch. Everything came together quickly and perfectly!
Easy to make and tasty following the recipe without any modifications.
To quote my hubby: "Awesome!"

This is the first recipe I tried with my new Crockpot Pressure cooker. I pressure cooked the meat for 1 and 1/2 hrs. (I live at 9300 ft elevation). I cooked the meat first, then steamed the potatoes and carrots after for 10 minutes. The potatoes and carrots were perfect and had such good flavor. Next time I will add 30 min. time to the meat since it didn't fall apart easily. A good meal!

Like so many others who reviewed, I modified a bit but largely followed the steps provided. 

I had a 2lb roast and followed the timing as written in the recipe but at high pressure. 

I didn't add potatoes and instead made a mashed potato to serve under the roast (it's just a preference) 

I browned onion and garlic along with the roast. Used the amount of broth listed in the recipe but added 1/2 cup of red wine. I always season the roast (and generously) before I brown - I pat into the meat to give it a good coating. Seasoning is key. 

Insanely delicious.
I made this using my pressure cooker for the first time ever! Soooo delicious! I did add extra seasonings because a pinch is never enough for me!
I followed the directions exactly. Flavor was very good. Meat was tough. We were disappointed.

I am giving this recipe a 3 star because I do believe that the 30 minute cooking time on low is not going to ever cook and tenderize a chuck/blade roast. I decided at the last minute to use a different recipe that cooks a 3 to 4 pound chuck/blade roast for 70 to 90 minutes on high. The roast came out the most tender, juicy and flavorful that I have ever tasted anywhere. The carrots, onions and potatoes went in at the start. The potatoes to use are the small ruby red potatoes, whole. With their skins on and the skins not pricked, they cook perfectly, tender but not mushy and the carrots most tender and flavorful. Cooked at 30 minutes on low would never cook a 3 pound chuck roast.

When the quantity is changed the time to cook needs to change. I looked extensively for time conversion tables but found nothing. My Power Pressure XL did a great job but I did change the time to 55 min. for round 1. I added the veggies and cooked for an additional 45 min. the roast for 8 people was 6 lbs. We had enough left over for one meal for 2. Whoever is cooking one 3 lb. roast for 8 is starving their guests. Otherwise, I cooked as directed and It's my go to from now on.

This came out delicious! I love recipes with Worcestershire sauce. It gives it such a rich taste. This was my first meal in my new pressure cooker. My 23 year old son could not stop raving about it while we were eating!

It was tender, but the recipe called for way too many veggies (I halved the carrots and potatoes and the final product was still more potatoes than meat) and the recipe calls for cooking the veggies too long. The potatoes were basically disintegrating. If you use an Instant Pot make the second cooking time a lot shorter.
